This photo was taken at the **Black Pyramid of Amenemhat III in Dahshur, Egypt.**

The structure in the image is a large, heavily eroded mud-brick pyramid. This core has suffered significant erosion and slumping due to its construction materials, giving it the distinctive rough, stepped, and dark appearance seen in the photograph. The people on the structure, dressed in traditional Egyptian or North African attire, appear to be working or examining the ancient monument, consistent with archaeological activity at such a site.

This photo was taken in **Warsaw, Poland**, specifically on **Próżna Street**.

The distinctive features that help identify this location are:
*   The unique historical brick building with its somewhat dilapidated state, which is characteristic of some pre-war structures in Warsaw that survived World War II.
*   The large-scale black and white photographs affixed to the facade of the building. These are a well-known art installation on Próżna Street, commemorating the former Jewish residents of the street and the surrounding area before and during World War II, when it was part of the Warsaw Ghetto. The upper large photo depicts people walking, and the lower individual portraits represent former inhabitants.

Próżna Street is one of the few streets in Warsaw where entire fragments of pre-war buildings survived the war relatively intact, and these photographic installations have been a prominent feature for years, drawing attention to the street's rich, yet tragic, history.
